title: 108_s1451
content: The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It includes amendments to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifically in Section 302 regarding findings. The Congress finds that youth who are homeless or run away from home without parental permission are at risk of serious health and behavioral problems. They lack resources for care and may live on the streets, creating law enforcement issues. These young people urgently need temporary shelter and linguistically appropriate services. The Federal Government should develop a national reporting system and effective care services for these youth. The Federal Government should develop a national reporting system and effective care services for runaway and homeless youth, including education, job skills, and employment opportunities. Improved coordination between Federal programs is necessary for a long-term strategy to address the needs of this population. SEC. 102. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to change the heading to "Basic Center". SEC. 103. Amends the Act to include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of youth. SEC. 104. Repeals obsolete provisions regarding certain allotments. SEC. 105. Establishes eligibility provisions. Section 311(b) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to streamline paragraphs and redesignate one. Section 312(a) is amended to replace "juveniles" with "youth". Section 312(b)(2)(A) is amended to recognize state laws regarding capacity limitations on eligible youth centers. Additionally, provisions for maternity group homes are included. SEC. 107 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to include maternity group homes, providing pregnant or parenting youth with supportive living arrangements and parenting skills. SEC. 108 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to extend shelter eligibility for youth under 18 until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the initial 540-day period. SEC. 109 updates coordination assurances for educational services, and SEC. 110 addresses coordination agreements. SEC. 110 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include coordination with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons to provide educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 111 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to develop a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services such as social, educational, vocational, legal, and health care programs. SEC. 112 focuses on the coordination of these programs. SEC. 112 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act emphasizes the coordination of programs and services for homeless youth, including consultation with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for better alignment. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority for activities under this title, while SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment to demonstration projects. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study, and SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study, and SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth seeking shelter in a center under part A. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations. Section 117 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act authorizes appropriations, specifying funding amounts for fiscal years 2004 to 2008 for different parts of the Act. This includes allocating funds for shelter services and grant obligations based on the quality and number of applicants. SEC. 118. REPORT ON PROMISING STRATEGIES TO END YOUTH HOMELESSNESS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness, must submit a report to Congress on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years of this Act. SEC. 119. STUDY OF HOUSING SERVICES AND STRATEGIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on housing programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to assess long-term housing outcomes for youth post-program. The study will focus on available housing services, assistance in finding permanent housing, and strategies to prevent future homelessness. SEC. 120. RESTRICTION ON USE OF FUNDS. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act will have a new section restricting the use of funds. SEC. 120. RESTRICTION ON USE OF FUNDS. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to restrict the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. Any entity receiving funds for this purpose must account for them separately. The Congress acknowledges the grave danger faced by abducted children and the risks of physical harm and exploitation. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various agencies to find missing children, as local resources may be insufficient for expanded search efforts. Coordination between local, State, and Federal law enforcement is crucial due to the frequent movement of abducted children. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various agencies nationally and internationally to find missing children and prevent child victimization. They operate a network linking with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, INTERPOL headquarters, and others to transmit images and information instantly to law enforcement worldwide. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This is part of the reauthorization of programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act.
